resources.string: 15th-century defensive fortress located on the Med. sea coast, in Alexandria.
It was built on a low plateau east of central Alexandria overlooking a beach on the Med. Sea.
A palace in Alexandria, named after John Antoniadis, who was an Alexandrian Greek. He was president of the Greek Community in Alexandria and consul general of Belgium.
One of the most significant libraries of the ancient world. It was dedicated to the Muses, the nine goddesses of the arts.
It was inaugurated the 31 December 2003 by Hosni Mubarak and it is located in a renovated Italian style palace in Tariq Al-Horreya Street.
A neighborhood near the city centre of Alexandria. The bridge has a total length of 400 meters with 6 spans on the Corniche.
A palace on the coast of the Med. Sea in Alexandria. It is one of the official residences for a serving President of Egypt. Under the Muhammad Ali Dynasty of Egypt.
The earthquake and tsunami that sank the island of Antirhodos occurred a few centuries after Cleopatra’s death, scattering the palace under about 10m of water in a bay.
The Abu al-Abbas Mosque is an Egyptian mosque in the city of Alexandria. It\'s dedicated to the 13th century Alexandrine Sufi saint Abul Abbas, whose tomb it contains.
An embankment dam built across the Nile in Aswan, between 1960–1970. Its significance largely eclipsed the previous Aswan Low Dam initially completed in 1902.
The Nile Museum exhibits antique items that tell of the waterway\'s history that illustrate the development of irrigation techniques since Ottoman rule.
An archaeological museum located in Aswan. Dedicated to Nubian culture and civilization.
Located at the south end of the Nile Corniche. The park has paved walkways that run along the east bank of the Nile and up high on Elephantine Island.
The twin temples were carved out of the mountainside in the 13th century BC, during the 19th dynasty reign of the Pharaoh Ramesses II.
Construction at the complex began during the reign of Senusret I in the Middle Kingdom and continued into the Ptolemaic period.
A valley in Egypt where, for a period from the 16th to 11th century BC, rock cut tombs were excavated for the Pharaohs and powerful nobles of the New Kingdom.
The 5,000 year-old Kebash Road in Luxor, which links the Karnak and Luxor temples. It\'s full of statues on sides
A free-standing concrete tower located in Cairo. At 187 m, it has been the tallest structure in Egypt and North Africa for about 50 years.
A medieval Islamic fortification in Cairo. The location, on Mokattam hill near the center of Cairo, was once famous for its fresh breeze and grand views of the city.
This park is listed as one of the world\'s sixty great public spaces. The park was created by the Historic Cities Support Programme of the Aga Khan Trust for Culture.
Is a home to an extensive collection of ancient Egyptian antiquities. It has 120,000 items, with a representative amount on display, the remainder in storerooms.
Is one of the oldest churches in Egypt and the history of a church in the 3rd century. It is named for its location above a gatehouse of Babylon Fortress.
An ancient fortress in the Delta of Egypt, located in Coptic Cairo. It was situated in the Heliopolite Nome, upon the east bank of the Nile, near the commencement of the Pharaonic Canal.
A major souk in the historic center of Islamic Cairo. The bazaar district is one of Cairo\'s main attractions for tourists and Egyptians alike.
A major public town square in Downtown Cairo, Egypt. The square has been the location for political demonstrations in Cairo, most notably those that led to the 2011 Egyptian revolution.
The 3 most famous Egyptian pyramids. The Pyramid of Khufu at Giza is the largest Egyptian pyramid. It is the only one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World still in existence.
Djoser\'s step pyramid was built during the Third Dynasty. Another 16 Egyptian kings built pyramids at Saqqara, which are now in various states of preservation or dilapidation.
An experience like no other. The instant you begin sailing down the canals that circuit through the island you are immersed totally in the Egypt of history and legend.
The Mastaba of Ti is the tomb of a court official who served three kings during the 5th Dynasty. It is perhaps the grandest and most detailed private tomb at Saqqara.
A historic house museum and biographical museum in Guiza.It is about the life, teaching, and residence of Taha Hussein who was one of the most influential Egyptian writers
Named after the poet Ahmed Shawki (1869–1932). After returning to Egypt, he built a new house at Giza which he named the new Karmet Ibn Hani. It was officially opened on June 1977.
The Pharaohs cruising restaurants are two masterpieces on the River Nile. Step aboard one of our boats and treat yourself to a two-hour escape in Pharaonic splendour.
It was an extremely important learning experience for the Egyptians. It provided them with the knowledge and know-how to transition from step-sided to smooth-sided pyramids.
